Title.evidence: This nonblinded, crossover, sequential randomized clinical trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This nonblinded, crossover, sequential randomized clinical trial with internal control

Participants.evidence: a volunteer sample of laypeople who attended a B-Con course at Gillette Stadium and the Longwood Medical Area in Boston, Massachusetts

Intervention.evidence: Full B-Con course, including cognitive and skill sessions, that taught bleeding care, wound pressure and packing, and CAT application.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To assess whether participants completing the American College of Surgeons Bleeding Control Basic (B-Con) training with Combat Application Tourniquets (CATs) can effectively apply bleeding control principles using other tourniquet types (commercial and improvised).

Method_Outcome.evidence: Correct tourniquet application (applied pressure of ≥250 mm Hg with a 2-minute time cap)

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The order of application varied for each participant using randomly generated permutated blocks.

Blinding.evidence: This nonblinded, crossover, sequential randomized clinical trial

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 102 participants (50 [49.0%] male; median [interquartile range] age, 37.5 [27.0-53.0] years) were included in the study.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 102 participants (50 [49.0%] male; median [interquartile range] age, 37.5 [27.0-53.0] years) were included in the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Participants correctly applied the CAT at a significantly higher rate (92.2%) than all other commercial tourniquet types (Special Operation Forces Tactical Tourniquet, 68.6%; Stretch-Wrap-and-Tuck Tourniquet, 11.8%; Rapid Application Tourniquet System, 11.8%) and the improvised tourniquet (32.4%) ( P < .001 for each pairwise comparison).
